moves.1. e4 c5 2. d4: Smith-Morra Gambit--something I like to try to open the game up right away. White gives up a pawn to get very active pieces on good squares.
moves.4. cxd4: cxd4? Nf3 was probably best to keep the gambit alive.
moves.4... d5: Striking back at the center for equality, although taking the pawn before is better just to make me prove I know what I'm doing.
moves.5. exd5 exd5 6. Nf3 Nf6: I'll play with this isolated pawn as White. e5 is my set-up point and the e file is the avenue for attack.
moves.7. Nc3 Bb4 8. Bd3 Qe7+: Qe7?! Not good--probably looking to trade queens.
moves.9... Nc6 10. O-O O-O: Black couldn't afford to keep the king out in the open any longer, and now his bishop at b4 is doing nothing.
moves.11. Re1: Now his misplacement of key pieces will be a problem.
moves.11... Nxe5 12. Rxe5 Be6 13. Bg5: Bg5! and now Black is completely tied up and pinned.
moves.13... Bxc3 14. bxc3: This to stay active, I suppose, but the king-side is the probem.
moves.14... h6 15. Bh4 Rac8 16. Qd2 a6 17. Rae: The kind of position I always try to  get: action on one side of the board, quiet on the other and a safe king.
moves.18... Qa3: Qa3? Still moving in the wrong areas.
moves.19. Bxf6 gxf6 20. Re5e3 Qf8 21. Rg3+ Kh8: And as a result, the wasted move by the queen and the smashed king position should decide things.
moves.28. Rh3: Rh3! Qxg4 leads to mate. The early queen move to e7 and the resulting pins led to a quick loss by Black in an equal position early in the opening.
